action.action-desc: Mr. Gaetz introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend title XIX of the Social Security Act to implement a minimum work requirement for able-bodied adults enrolled in State Medicaid programs.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Medicaid Work Requirements Act.
Section 1902 of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1396a) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking and at the end of paragraph (86);
by striking the period at the end of paragraph (87) and inserting ; and; and
by inserting after paragraph (87) the following new paragraph:

paragraph.text: beginning October 1, 2023, not provide medical assistance with respect to a month to an able-bodied adult (as defined in subsection (uu)(2)) that has not met the work requirement described in subsection (uu)(1) for such month.
by adding at the end the following new subsection:

For purposes of subsection (a)(88), the work requirement described in this subsection with respect to an able-bodied adult and a month is that such adult satisfies at least one of the following with respect to such month:

subparagraph.text: The adult works 120 hours or more per month, or has a month income that is at least equal to the federal minimum wage, multiplied by 120 hours.
The adult volunteers for 80 hours or more per month.
The adult participates in a work program for at least 80 hours a month.
The adult participates in a combination of work, including volunteer work, and a work program for a total of at least 80 hours per month.
The term able-bodied adult means any individual who is not—

clause.text: under 18 years of age or over 65 years of age;
physically or mentally unfit for employment, as determined by a physician or other medical professional;
the parent or caretaker of a dependent child under 6 years of age;
the parent or caretaker of an incapacitated person;
complying with work requirements under a different program under State or Federal law;
participating in a drug or alcohol treatment and rehabilitation program (as defined in section 3(h) of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008); or
enrolled in a college or university, or a training program, at least half time.

subparagraph.text: The term incapacitated person means an individual who is incapable of making decisions concerning the provision, withholding, or withdrawal of foods, liquid, or medical treatment under applicable law.

clause.text: a program approved by the Secretary of Labor pursuant to section 236(a) of the Trade Act of 1974; or
an employment or training program operated by a State or a political subdivision of a State.
